page.title: 02GEOLOGY OF BEDGEBURY AREA
page.content: This area is in the High Weald which is the hilly, wooded central core of the Weald. The local rocks are the Hastings Beds, a lacustrine deltaic deposit of Early Cretaceous times (c. 120 million years ago), which has three major sub- divisions, i.e. Tunbridge Wells Sand over Wadhurst Clay over Ashdown Sand. The Sands are mainly very fine yellow or whitish sand that in places is cemented into sandstone rock. Wadhurst Clay is usually a greyish silty mudstone that weathers to a yellow brown silty clay. The outcrop of the sub-divisions is highly variable due to faulting and river erosion which has carved this part of the country into its present shape. The south half of the block is mainly Tunbridge Wells Sand, the north roughly divided between sand and clay.
